title: Sort an Array of 0, 1 & 2
description: Given an array containing only 0s, 1s, and 2s, sort the array in-place using a single pass, such that all 0s come first, followed by 1s, and then 2s.

approaches.description: Count the occurrences of 0s, 1s, and 2s and overwrite the array accordingly.
steps: Traverse the array once to count the number of 0s, 1s, and 2s.
Rewrite the array: fill it with 0s, then 1s, then 2s using the counters.

approaches.description: Use three pointers to sort the array in a single traversal: low for 0s, mid for current element, high for 2s.
steps: Initialize three pointers: low = 0, mid = 0, high = nums.length - 1.
- If nums[mid] == 0: swap with nums[low], increment both low and mid.
- If nums[mid] == 2: swap with nums[high], decrement high (do not move mid).

examples.explanation: Each unique color is sorted in order.
Single 0 moved to the front, rest are 1s.

edge_cases.reason: Only one element in the array.

notes.why_dnf_works: The Dutch National Flag algorithm efficiently partitions the array into three segments using constant space and one traversal.
notes.always_linear: Regardless of input order, the optimal solution makes one pass, hence always O(n).

hints: Try solving using counting sort first.
Can you sort the array in one pass with constant space?
Think of a three-pointer approach: one for each segment.
follow_up: Can you generalize this approach for arrays with more than three distinct values?
How would this work in a linked list version of the problem?
What changes would be required to make this stable (preserve original order)?
